newsitem.title: HONG KONG: PRESS DIGEST-Hong Kong newspaper headlines-May 8.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Hong Kong newspaper headlines-May 8.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Hong Kong press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- WEN WEI PO -- Hong Kong's future leader Tung Chee-hwa met Chinese vice-premier Qian Qichen and discussed how the legislative council of the Special Administrative Region (SAR), as the territory will be known after its handover to China on July 1, should be set up. Tung denied intending to introduce a ministerial system in Hong Kong.
-- MING PAO -- The Consumer Council warned that because property developers had stopped pre-sales, the government's measures to stop property speculation might fail to have a major effect.

-- ECONOMIC TIMES -- Jardine Matheson's relationship with Beijing had a major breakthrough after its chairman met with Chinese vice-premier Zhu Rongji. The biggest private organisation in Hong Kong expressed its confidence in the territory's future.

-- ECONOMIC JOURNAL -- China United Telecommunications (China Unicom) said it had been allowed by the Chinese government to be the second telecommunications company on the mainland, while its chief executive confirmed the company's intention to acquire a stake in Hongkong Telecom.
-- HONGKONG STANDARD -- Tung called on Beijing to be flexible over the formation of the SAR legislative council.
-- Wharf Cable was poised to present a threat to Asia Television and Television Broadcasts following the passage of a law allowing Cable TV to carry commercial advertisements.

-- SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- China was accused of "nuclear blackmail" in the United States, while Washington came under fire for allegedly allowing China to sell Iran advanced weaponry built with U.S. technology.
